segments.text: Certainly in that particular situation, it was a gross misrepresentation of the facts.
That was simply not the case.
a non-issue, if you will.
There was not that much involved.
I can't help but, in retrospect, or looking at it from the current perspective, wonder just exactly what the situation is in other demonstrations, if you will.
I'm untrusting of what I see presented in the media as a major situation.
I think that, well, I fear that in many situations what looks like a major demonstration may be just a very small group making a very large amount of noise.
Actually, the only personal confrontation I had with Savio and his followers was, I guess in retrospect, a somewhat humorous situation that came up.
When I was at Berkeley working on my doctorate, I did my research work at the Lawrence Radiation Laboratory up on the hill.
And it was literally up on a hill.
It was a long, steep road going up to the laboratories.
At that time, I managed to get back and forth between home and the laboratories on a Vespa motor scooter, which was not the most powerful device I've ever had the privilege to drive around.

In order to get to the laboratory on the Vespa, I would have to wind it up like a top at the bottom of the hill and roar with all my heart right up to the back door, because if I didn't, if I slowed down on the way up the hill, I simply couldn't make it.
I would literally have to get off and push that brute all the way to the top of the hill.
There was...

One situation when Savio, trying to make some point, I have not the foggiest notion as to what it was at that time, but they decided that they were going to boycott the Rad Lab, and various members of Savio's following
most of which, incidentally, I don't think had any idea as to what they were trying to say or what their demonstration was about.
But they blockaded or tried to blockade the laboratory, and they did it by means of setting up effectively human barricades on the road.
Well, I didn't know what they were doing, but I came to work one morning, and with my usual technique, I
wound the Vespa up at the bottom of the hill, and I was going hell-bent for thunder for the top.
And here they were, standing in front of me, waving placards at me.
And there was no way I was going to push that Vespa all the way to the top of that hill, so I just kept on going.
And I'm afraid that Savio's followers ended up thrashing rather vigorously in the bushes by the time I got by.
But it's...
I didn't really feel like I was doing the system any real justice.
I simply was going to work.
Very recently there's been a good deal of publicity given to a group called the Union of Concerned Scientists and their claims of the danger of

of the nuclear industry and nuclear energy as a as a source has been fairly widespread what are your perceptions of their claims or or of their group and have you had any personal dealing with them i've certainly had no personal dealings with them i got a number of flyers from them through the mail and i get a lot of that kind of information and after i'd

glanced at the first couple of them I decided that I would probably have to deal with it as just more junk mail and I very frankly haven't followed them that closely it's my understanding that this is a group of
of well-educated personnel that are very concerned about the use of nuclear reactors or nuclear power in this country.
I guess I, to a certain extent, have to regard that type of movement as principally being, well, as I say,
well-educated but uninformed non-experts.
They don't really know the technical details of the nuclear industry, and I frankly feel, and this is a personal opinion, I frankly feel that most of their concerns are completely unfounded, and I

Although they certainly have the right to espouse whatever opinions they choose to hold, I am concerned, again from a personal perspective, that they are in fact doing the country and modern society something of a disservice dealing with it in the way that they do.

and not being specific with regards to the Union of Concerned Scientists, but I think other anti-nuclear movements or groups in general, generally deal with the nuclear question in terms of scare tactics.
And many of them understand more than they would generally, one might generally suppose that they do.
But as far as I'm concerned, they deal with things from the point of view of fear.
They try to frighten people rather than inform them.
Many of the claims that they make are totally specious and are technically, I think, verging on the absurd.
I think that it's certainly true that the
the use of nuclear reactors nuclear power is not to be regarded as a trivial risk there is risk associated with with the devices i think there is no question about it there are situations albeit
situations that are very, very improbable in my estimation that can be dangerous.
And the fact that people are concerned about them is not at all surprising or inappropriate.

think that when you're dealing with the hazardous situation or a hazardous device it is only it only makes sense for people to try to inform themselves as best they can with regards to the real hazard and what the basis for real concern is and if one

on the basis of the facts, comes to the conclusion that the hazard is higher than is appropriate or than can be, well, in this particular case, from a societal point of view, can be tolerated, then that particular line should not be pursued.
I think, however, that is not the way that the nuclear issue is being handled.
I frankly feel that much of the way that people are handling it almost comes under the category of intentional obfuscation, the confuse,
provide misinformation rather than trying to clarify the situation, they make it as murky as possible and make it as confused as possible.
And that is an approach that I frankly simply have no tolerance for.
Recent presidential administrations have taken fairly strong stands either for or against nuclear energy as a national resource.
Can you detail some of your perspectives of President Carter and then President Reagan's policy concerning nuclear power?
SECRETARY KERRY, Let me begin with President Carter's administration.
From the perspective of the nuclear industry, President Carter's administration was essentially a disaster.
And let me hasten to note that what I'm going to say now is strictly a personal opinion, but in my estimation,

the stands, if you will, that the Carter administration took with regards to nuclear power were effectively based on what is almost a total lack of understanding, in my estimation, with regards to the purpose and function hazards or lacks of hazards with regards to nuclear power.
President Carter, I think, started out his administration on the wrong foot with regards to the nuclear industry.
I think his, where he really shot himself in the foot was when he contended that he was a nuclear engineer.
He was taken to task on that point very rapidly.
I think his

closest association with things nuclear was the fact that he had spent some few weeks or a month or whatever on a nuclear submarine and in his estimation that was sufficient to allow him to contend that he was in fact a nuclear engineer.
He was very quickly called on that point and
Once it came to issue, it became a very quiet issue as far as the administration was concerned.
He was not, he doesn't understand or didn't understand the potential values of nuclear power.
And I think that he did the industry as a whole a severe disservice, principally out of ignorance.
And that bothers me, that that kind of situation could cause the damage that it did.
Do you believe that the current administration has taken any steps to correct the attitude that was held by President Carter's administration?
Okay, the Reagan administration.
I think that the Reagan administration is much more realistic in their approach to nuclear power.
They have one, certainly one major item that they are pushing.
and possibly not at all inappropriate, but President Reagan would like to turn the function of nuclear power development over to the private sector.
That, I think, has some virtue.
However, from a pragmatic point of view, I'm not sure that it's that realistic.
The reason I say that is that

in general most of the the nuclear power systems that are potentially available for development involve times amounts of money and risk that is financial risk that is still inappropriate for the private sector i think that to a very major extent it's going to be very difficult
to talk the private sector into getting involved in a very major way in the development of major nuclear power systems.
I think one of the reasons is that the private sector simply is not very trusting of the national
system, if you will, they were very badly mistreated during the Carter administration in the sense that they were regulated almost out of existence.
Governmental regulations were conceived of and put into effect that almost destroyed the nuclear power

development that was going on the private sector had a great deal of money and still has a great deal of money involved or committed to development of nuclear power and because of of regulate regulatory stands that the government took they were effectively hamstrung
and it cost an absolutely ferocious amount of money.

And I think that in general the private sector is going to be very reluctant to get back into that situation where they have effectively put their own money at risk, realizing that the government could effectively hamstring them at any minute.
think that they're going to be very reluctant in the future to move with any kind of vigor into that kind of a situation again.
During the last few years, one of the strongest and most vocal proponents of the nuclear programs in Washington and within the administrations
was Admiral Hyman Rickover in his various capacities as nuclear advisor to the president or to Congress.
When he was retired, that was quite a commotion.
Do you see his retirement as a positive influence on the national programs?
And what are your perspectives of Admiral Rickover's recent work?
I certainly have never had any direct involvement with Admiral Rickover.

Just as a personal opinion, I think that over the years his influence has been a very positive one, not only from the perspective of the nuclear industry, but just generally from a social point of view.
I think he's been a very positive influence.
I think that he obviously did a very fine job in getting the nuclear navy in place, the nuclear subs in particular, I think can be given to Admiral Rickover as a very positive accomplishment.
He, I think in some situations, went a little further than was practically advisable.
that is trying to develop a surface Navy that was atomic powered was something that was really before its time, if its time ever does come.
But I think with regards to the nuclear sub fleet that we have now, that is essentially a
something that Admiral Rickover was essentially responsible for in a fairly personal way.
I think that currently, well, that is the commotion that you referred to with regards to his retirement, I think Admiral Rickover

did a fine job, and I think that during the time that he was working effectively, he was a very positive influence, that everybody comes to the end of their rope, and I think that the Admiral had just about outlived his technological usefulness, and so I think that the fact that he was retired when he was was essentially appropriate.
In light of the current research and the current information available, what do you see as the state of the art in technology in specific regard to plutonium technology?
That question covers a very, very wide range of activities.
I think that, well, let me say that plutonium is a material that is, from a scientific point of view, is very fascinating to work with.
It has a very complex chemistry.
It has an extremely complex metallurgy.
I think there is obviously a great deal of work that is being done and needs to be done in the future from a purely scientific point of view.
I think that there are a number of developments that are in the offing.
for instance, with regards to the metallurgy of plutonium that are of potential great value to the weapons programs in the country.
I think there's a great deal of very interesting work that is being done.
And I think that certainly significant developments relative to the
manufacture of plutonium and the processing of plutonium in one light or another that will be a substantial advantage with regards to the weapons industry.
In other areas, for instance, reactor fuels, there's a great deal of work to be done there.
The principal place where plutonium is used in the reactor industry is with regards to the development and operation of, at the present time, liquid metal fast breeder reactors.
That is the primary place where plutonium would be used in the reactor industry.
There's a great deal to be done there.
Frankly, I think that the LMFBR industry in the United States is operating at a severe disadvantage.
Well, and by disadvantage I mean that the LMFBR development in this country has been very heavily
well, has been held back to a very major extent because of the regulatory problems that I mentioned a moment ago.
Well, the development of LMFBRs in this country is very substantially behind that in many of the other major countries around the world.
The French, for instance, are really at the forefront of development.
The Germans are working.
The British have a substantial amount going that is significantly in advance of what we're doing now.
Unfortunately, it's really kind of interesting with the fact that because of the anti-nuclear movements,

and the various regulatory problems that the LMFBR people have run into in this country that led to the LMFBR being effectively downplayed or downgraded has had an interesting reflection in some of the European countries that were vigorously moving toward the development of an LMFBR.

we began to back up and for some reason they started backing up too and it's almost as though it was a the system became unstable to a certain extent and much of the the pressure or impetus if you will to the development of LMFBRs has begun to to lose its momentum
And that I personally feel is going to be a very major problem not very many years into the future.
I can see very major difficulties on the horizon with regards to the availability of power.
And the LMFBR was originally
intended to help close that gap.
But it's beginning to appear to me that that gap is not only not being closed, we're losing ground on it.
And there may be, there may come a time when the power situation in the world will make us all rue the day that the LNFBR was
What are the problems with the LMFBR that inspire the over-regulation or the dissent against that program?
I think the dissent is primarily based on concerns with safety.
There are several scenarios, many of which in my estimation are simply not credible.
that lead some to feel that the LMFBR is simply not safe to have in the country.
They envision LMFBRs, or reactors in general, as effectively being a
a bomb sitting there waiting to explode, and that simply is not the case.
They cannot explode in that way.
I must hasten to add that reactors are not without risk.
There are things that can happen that can cause problems.
However, I think many of the problems that are

effectively suggested as being probable are really extremely unlikely situations and I think they're just not at all, they're so unlikely that they really in my estimation should be of no major concern.
One of the other things that is leading to concern about the LMFBR is the fact that
many people, and I'm sure they are expert in their area, are suggesting that uranium reserves in this country are such that the LMFBR truly is not needed.
And by that I mean that you can operate power reactors as
as the light water reactors are operated now.
You simply burn the uranium and throw away the fission products and that's that.
And you don't have any mechanism for continuing to grow new fissile material.
That is the virtue of the breeder.
It effectively manufactures more fuel than it burns.
That is fine as long as you have
of sufficient uranium to keep the system operating effectively ad infinitum.
I, frankly, am not very comfortable with that new plan.
I'm afraid we're going to need it over here, and it may be too late once it's really recognized as being needed.

Dr. Green, in conclusion, do you feel that since its conception that the nuclear industry or the field of nuclear research has advanced, and if so, do you believe that it will continue to be a viable source or an energy program in the future?
Well, I think from a technological point of view, over the few years that the industry has been in existence, technologically there have been tremendous advances.
Unfortunately, it almost appears like, in a political sense, the industry has been marching backwards.
That is to say that its acceptance by the man on the street has degraded very dramatically and in a very discouraging way, as far as I'm concerned.
It's really too bad, I think, that people have developed such a mistrust.
And I think that, as I said earlier, I think a great deal of that mistrust is born of fear, and most of the fear is born in ignorance.
And I wish we could turn that around.
